On 26 December 2004, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake near Sumatra sent 
several  tsunami  waves  that  struck  over  two  thirds  of  Sri  Lanka’s 
coastline and caused catastrophic destruction; more than 31,000 people 
in Sri Lanka died and thousands more are still missing. Another 440,000 
people are displaced, with the tsunami-affected population estimated at 
between 1 and 2 million, out of a total population of about 19 million.

Rationale 

 Nearly 100,000 houses were destroyed during the tsunami and another 
46,000 were damaged. Infrastructure and fishing industry assets such as 
boats were damaged or lost. About 60% of the damage occurred on the 
east and northeast coasts.  
 
A joint tsunami needs assessment, in cooperation with the Government 
and the Task Force for Rebuilding the Nation, was undertaken by ADB, 
the  World  Bank,  and  the  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation,  in 
concert  with  United  Nations  agencies.  Tsunami-related  financing  needs 
for rebuilding are estimated to be approximately $1.5 billion. In the short 
term, the majority of resources are required for housing, transportation, 
institutional  and  community  infrastructure,  livelihood  restoration  for 
fishermen  and  small-scale  farmers,  and  small  and  micro-enterprise 
assistance.  
 
The  coastal  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces  have  only 
recently begun to emerge from the devastating effects of nearly 20 years 
of civil conflict when the tsunami hit. The conflict left over 65,000 dead, 
several  times  as  many  people  disabled,  and  nearly  800,000  people 
displaced  from  their  homes.  A  large  percentage  of  people  directly 
affected by the conflict still suffer from a lack of basic infrastructure and 
social services. A cease-fire agreement signed by the Government and 
the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam 3 years before the tsunami hit had 
enabled  a  period  of  reconciliation  and  restoration  in  the  North  East. 
However, many villages and much of the coastal infrastructure that had 
been  rebuilt  after  the  cease-fire  were  destroyed  by  the  tsunami.  Many 
other assets that had withstood the conflict were lost in the tsunami.  
 
After  the  cease-fire,  a  comprehensive  conflict  needs  assessment  was 
presented

community  has  committed  about  $700 million––to  address  both 
immediate  and  medium-term  needs.  This  leaves  at  least  $80  million  of 
the immediate needs unmet.

The  pre-tsunami  conditions  and  the  situation  in  the  North  East  make  it 
difficult to demarcate tsunami- and conflict-related rebuilding efforts. The 
tsunami  needs  assessment  emphasized  the  importance  of  key  guiding 
principles—such  as  conflict  sensitivity,  subsidiarity,  community 
risk  management,  and 
transparency,  multi-hazard 
empowerment, 
coordination  between  stakeholders—during 
the  development  of  a 
comprehensive  recovery  strategy.  The  international  community  has 
responded  generously  with  pledges  of  tsunami  assistance.  However, 
provision  of  significant  assistance  to  tsunami-affected  people  may 
produce  tensions  if  it  is  perceived  that  different  parts  of  the  country  or 
ethnic  groups  are  receiving  more  than  their  fair  share  of  reconstruction 
funds, or if other people who are in poverty, or internally displaced from 
the conflict, feel they are being forgotten. By providing assistance at the 
same  time  and  with  a  similar  delivery  framework  and  policies  to  both 
tsunami- and conflict-affected areas, the risk of creating a perception of 
unequal  treatment  of  people  affected  by  either  calamity  will  be 
minimized.  
 
Recognizing the urgent needs and the social services and infrastructure 
lost  as  a  result  of  the  tsunami  and  the  20-year  conflict,  both  projects 
have been processed under ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance 
Policy.  TAARP  will  complement  and  augment  other  projects  in  the 
tsunami-affected  areas,  benefiting 
the  current  extensive 
coordination  mechanisms  established  among  external  parties. 
NECORD-II also coordinates well with other projects planned or ongoing 
in the North East and will reinforce the perception that the international 
community remains involved with and supports the peace process.  The 
Project  will  also  confirm  ADB’s  leading  role  in  rehabilitation  and  peace 
building  operations  in  the  North  East,  the  country’s  most  impoverished 
and vulnerable region, which was also hit particularly hard by the effects 
of the tsunami.  
 
The  objective  of  TAARP  is  to  rapidly  improve  the  living  conditions  and 
well-being  of  a  significant  number  of  people  in  the  tsunami-affected 
areas  by  restoring  basic  social  infrastructure,  community  and  public 
services,  and  livelihoods.  TAARP  will  address  the  needs  of  tsunami-
affected  people  through  numerous  subprojects  in  a  variety  of  sectors 
selected  and  formulated  in  response  to  requests  from  tsunami-affected 
people and the Government. Other subprojects will be designed as part 
of  the  restoration  and  expansion  of  ongoing  ADB  interventions  in  order

The Government has requested a loan of $26 million and a grant of $14 
million  from  the  ADB  Asian  Development  Fund  for  the  unmet  needs  of 
the  conflict-affected  North  East.  The  loans  will  have  a  40-year  term, 
including a grace period of 10 years, with repayment of principal at 2% 
per  year  for  the  first  10  years  after  the  grace  period  and  4%  a  year 
thereafter. The terms and conditions of the grants will be as set forth in 
the Financing and Project Agreements presented to the Board.  
 
Until 30 June 2009 for both projects 
 
 
Both  projects  will  be  implemented  through  project  management  units 
(PMUs)  already  established  under  other  ongoing  loans  in  the  portfolio, 
except  for  the  governance  component.  Each  PMU  will  address  a  need 
according  to  its  present  strength  and  area  of  coverage.  The  PMUs  will 
generally  be  responsible  to  different  executing  agencies,  according  to 
the existing arrangements of their parent loan projects.  
 
A  National  Project  Coordination  Committee  chaired  by  the  Secretary, 
Ministry of Finance and Planning, will be established to provide oversight 
and coordination. Members will come from the Task Force for Rebuilding 
the  Nation,  the  Ministry  of  Justice  and  Judicial  Affairs,  the  Ministry  of 
Defense,  other  ministries,  departments,  and  agencies  responsible  for 
tsunami--related  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation,  ADB; 
the  chief 
secretaries  of  the  Southern  and  North  East  Provincial  Councils;  ADB 
project directors; and others as appropriate. The committee will meet at 
least  quarterly  and  oversee  overall  project  coordination  and 
implementation at the national level.  
 
To  ensure  beneficiary  participation  during  project  preparation  and 
implementation,  sector  subprojects  will  generally  be  prepared  for  and 
approved by a provincial project coordination committee. The North East 
Provincial  Council  currently  performs  this  function  very  effectively  for 
ADB  projects  in  the  North  East.  Consultants  funded  by  technical 
assistance  will  help  to  adopt  this  system  in  the  Southern  Provincial 
Council.

The  vast  majority  of  those  directly  affected  by  the  tsunami  were  at  the 
lower  end  of  the  economic  scale,  partly  because  the  districts  affected 
tended  to  have  high  levels  of  poverty  at  the  time  of  the  disaster  and 
partly because people who lived in substandard housing were less able 
to resist the onslaught of the waves.  
 
In  the  conflict-affected  North  East,  poverty  levels  are  estimated  to  be 
60%–90%,  much  higher  than  in  the  rest  of  the  country,  although  there 
are gaps in government surveys for much of the area.  
 
Together,  the  two  projects  will  address  urgent  needs  of  approximately 
3 million people, among whom the physically disabled, single heads-of-
households,  and  children  feature  significantly.  By  restoring  sectors  that 
form  the  backbone  of  the  economy  in  affected  areas,  the  projects  will 
help to rebuild communities and stabilize the economic base of the local 
populations,  helping  them  to  move  from  dependency  on  government 
support towards sustainable livelihoods.  
 
Proactive  HIV/AIDS  awareness  programs 
in  NECORD-II  will  be 
undertaken  in  the  rapidly-expanding  construction  industry  in  the  North 
East.  Programs  in  NECORD-II  will  also  support  gender  enterprise 
initiatives  in  the  North  East  to  address  the  needs  of  the  many  conflict 
widows,  reduce  their  dependency  on  government  support,  and  secure 
sustainable livelihoods for them.

The  designs  of  TAARP  and  NECORD-II  incorporate  safeguards  to

RATIONALE: ANALYSIS, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Tsunami Impact and Needs Assessment 

 
A. 
 
2. 
In the morning of Sunday 26 December 2004, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake off Sumatra 
sent  several  tsunami  waves  radiating  out  into  the  Bay  of  Bengal,  the  Andaman  Sea,  and  the 
Indian  Ocean.  These  waves  struck  over  two  thirds  of  Sri  Lanka’s  coastline1  and  caused 
catastrophic destruction and considerable loss of life (see map).  
 
As of February 2005, official figures indicated that over 31,000 people in Sri Lanka lost 
3. 
their  lives  in  the  tsunami,  thousands  more  remain  missing,  and  over  440,000  were  displaced. 
The tsunami-affected population is between 1 and 2 million people, out of a total population of 
about 19 million.  
 
4. 
In the wake of the disaster, the Government, as part of its reconstruction plan to address 
tsunami  damage,  launched  a  needs  assessment  and,  within  days,  prepared  an  inventory  of 
damage and losses. Three task forces were assembled to address the disaster, with the Task 
Force  for  Rebuilding  the  Nation  (TAFREN),  assigned  to  address  reconstruction  needs.  At  a 
meeting  in  late  December  2004,  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  and  the  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation (JBIC), in coordination with the United Nations (UN), assisted the Government to 
develop  a  coastal  area  reconstruction  needs  assessment  to  serve  as  a  platform  for  all 
development partners interested in contributing to this effort.  
 
5. 
The  first  phase  of  the  needs  assessment,  conducted  with  technical  assistance  from 
ADB,2  began  in  early  January  2005.  The  damage  caused  by  the  tsunami  was  surveyed  and 
estimates  of  the  financing  requirements  for  post-tsunami  construction  were  refined.  Weekly 
meetings  were  held  by  multilateral  and  bilateral  agencies,  UN  organizations,  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and civil society. A preliminary report was presented on 28 January 2005 
(Appendix 2 contains a summary of the needs assessment findings).  
 
6. 
Tsunami-related  financing  needs  for  national  rebuilding  are  estimated  to  be  over 
$1.5 billion,  in  addition  to  the  $200  million-$300 million  that  the  Government  estimates  it  has 
already spent, and excluding further relief expenditures. The fiscal impact of the tsunami will be 
more  long  term,  given  that  estimated  rebuilding  costs  will  be  the  equivalent  of  almost  7%  of 
annual gross domestic product.

The  Government  estimates  that  nearly  100,000 houses  were  destroyed  during  the 
7. 
tsunami and another 46,000 were damaged. Nearly 170 public schools, 4 universities, and 18 
vocational and training centers were affected. The health sector suffered not only from damage 
to health-related infrastructure, but also through loss of services and human resources. Coastal 
courts  and  labor  tribunals,  prisons,  and  police  stations,  and  district  offices  that  contained 
personal and property documents were partially or completely destroyed.  
 
8. 
About 1,400 kms of the national and provincial road network, and another 1,100 kms of 
local  and  village  access  roads  were  damaged.  Bridges  and  culverts  were  also  destroyed  or 
displaced  and  embankments  were  eroded  by  the  advancing  and  retreating  tsunami.  Flooding 
before  and  after  the  tsunami  along  the  east  coast  further  damaged  the  road  network.  The 
tsunami  destroyed  several  sections of  coastal  railway  lines,  in  particular  on  the  Southern  Line 
between Colombo and Galle along the Southwest coast. Water supply schemes and distribution 
networks  along  the  shoreline  were  impacted,  along  with  at  least  12,000  water  wells  damaged 
mainly  by  saltwater  intrusion;  about  50,000  others  were  abandoned.  Salinity  contamination  of 
stand crops in paddy and other crop fields or home gardens will limit or inhibit crop production 
for the next 3 to 4 years, until salinity is naturally flushed away through rain.  
 
9. 
The  damaged  sustained  to  coastal  livelihoods  ranges  from  destroyed  fishing  boats  to 
damaged  informal  guesthouses,  through  the  loss  of  business  inventories  to  the  loss  of  simple 
tools  and  workshops.  About  65%  of  the  nation’s  sea  fishing  boat  fleet  was  either  damaged  or 
destroyed. About 3,500 hotel rooms out of about 14,000 rooms in medium to large-scale hotels 
are  not  in  operation.  In  the  small  guesthouses,  about  1,200  rooms  out  of  a  total  4,000  have 
been affected.  
 
10. 
The second phase of the tsunami needs assessment process started in February 2005 
under  the  supervision  of  a  steering  committee  made  up  of  many  stakeholders.3  The  main 
objectives  of  phase  II  are:  (i)  to  finalize  the  damage  assessment  figures  by  consulting  with 
TAFREN  and  other  stakeholders  and  to  arrive  at  a  consensus  on  reconstruction  needs  and 
financing requirements; and (ii) to develop implementation strategies for responding equitably to 
the  needs  of  the  tsunami-affected  communities  that  will  guide  all  parties  engaged  in  post-
tsunami  reconstruction.  The  second  phase  will  involve  a  thorough  consultative  process 
conducted  in  districts  by  multisectoral  teams  drawn  from  TAFREN,  the  donor  community,  civil 
society, the private sector, and other stakeholders. These strategies will be completed by mid-
April 2005.  
 
B. 
 
11. 
The  coastal  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces  had  only  recently  begun  to 
emerge  from  the  devastating  effects  of  the  nearly  20-year  civil  conflict  between  the 
Government’s armed forces and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) when the tsunami 
hit. The lengthy civil conflict left over 65,000 dead, several times as many people disabled, and 
nearly 800,000 people displaced from their homes. In February 2002, the Government and the 
LTTE  signed  a  cease-fire  agreement,  thereby  beginning  a  period  of  reconciliation,  restoration, 
and reconstruction. However, a large percentage of people directly affected by the conflict still 
lack basic infrastructure and social services.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

In early 2003, multilateral agencies operating in Sri Lanka4 undertook a comprehensive 
12. 
assessment  of  reconstruction  needs  for  the  conflict-affected  areas,  primarily  in  the  eight 
districts5 that make up the North East (see map). The assessment, which was presented to the 
international community at the Sri Lanka Reconstruction and Development Conference held in 
Tokyo  in  June  2003,6  identified  about  $2 billion  for  immediate  and  medium-term  needs,  and 
$1 billion  for  longer-term  needs.  Of  this  $2  billion,  about  $780  million  was  identified  for 
immediate  needs,  and  about  $1.2  billion  was  identified  for  medium-term  needs.  To  date,  the 
international  community  has  committed  about  $700 million––to  address  both  immediate  and 
medium-term needs. This leaves at least $80 million of the immediate needs unmet.  
 
C. 
 
The tsunami needs assessment emphasized the importance of key guiding principles—
13. 
such  as  conflict  sensitivity,  subsidiarity,  community  empowerment,  transparency,  multi-hazard 
risk  management,  and  coordination  between  stakeholders—during  the  development  of  a 
comprehensive  recovery  strategy.  The  guiding  principles,  which  have  been  agreed  by  all 
concerned  parties,  are  presented  in  Appendix 3.  The  international  community  has  responded 
generously  with  pledges  of  tsunami  assistance.  However,  if  not  approached  and  delivered 
sensitively, the provision of this tsunami assistance could risk exacerbating preexisting tensions, 
by creating a perception of unequal treatment of people affected by the conflict.  
 
14. 
In addition to the problems and needs described above (paragraphs 6-9), the destruction 
wrought  by  the  tsunami  has  generated  legal  issues  for  tsunami-affected  people,  including  the 
loss of documents: titles to property; birth, death, and marriage certificates; identification cards; 
court  records;  and  bank  account  documents.  They  also  face  family,  custody,  adoption, 
inheritance, insurance, property rights and entitlement issues. The Department of the Registrar 
General  (within  the  Ministry  of  Public  Security,  Law  and  Order)  is  attempting  to  reissue  birth, 
death and marriage certificates, and the Department of the Registration of Persons (within the 
Ministry  of  Public  Security,  Law  and  Order),  is  attempting  to  issue  identification  cards  to  all 
tsunami-affected  persons.  To  the  extent  copies  of  documents  remain,  record-keeping  and 
retrieval  in  these  departments  is  currently  manually  done,  making  it  almost  impossible  to 
respond to some requests for replacement documents. Data collection from tsunami victims has 
level 
not  been  coordinated  amongst  departments.  Additionally,  divisional  and  district 
government officials (district secretaries, divisional secretaries, and grama niladhari7) will need 
to  understand  the  new  legal  requirements,  and  document  processing  procedures  and  to 
proceed  along  appropriate  channels.  They  will  need  legal  assistance  to  resolve  any  legal 
questions that may arise. In the tsunami-affected areas, already poor and vulnerable people will 
have  difficulty  negotiating  formal  avenues,  and  clearly  need  assistance  if  they  are  to  benefit 
from  the  new  laws  and  procedures.  In  addition,  the  legal  and  factual  issues  generated  by  the 
tsunami  are  likely  to  lead  to  increased  disputes  and  grievances,  both among  tsunami-affected 
people, and possibly against government officers and departments. The volume and scale of all 
tsunami-assistance  provided  to  Sri  Lanka  could  also  lead  to  corruption.  Current  institutional 
structures may not be sufficient.

disposal  costs.  The  dumping  of  debris  in  inappropriate  locations  must  be  addressed

16. 
Because  of  Sri  Lanka’s  vulnerability  to  global  warming,  climate  change,  sea  level  rise, 
and  extreme  weather  events,  the  United  Nations  Environment  Programme  (UNEP)  and  other 
development  partners  are  currently  conducting  environmental  assessments  of  the  devastation 
caused by the tsunami. Their objective is to identify follow-on projects and further studies in the 
likelihood  of  similar  or  localized  natural  disasters  in  the  future,  including  the  role  of  natural 
resources in minimizing the effect of natural disasters. As a result of the assessment by UNEP 
and its partners, tsunami reconstruction subprojects need to identify ways to (i) respond to the 
vulnerability  of  coastal  populations  to  such  disasters;  (ii) prevent  or  reduce  the  magnitude  of 
such  disasters;  (iii) educate  coastal  populations  on  disaster  preparedness  and  mitigation; 
(iv) improve  information  and  communication  systems;  and  (v) enhance  coastal  protection 
through  natural  barriers  such  as  green  zones  or  green  belts  of  forests,  coastal  vegetation,  or 
mangroves.  
 
17. 
Both  disasters  have  radically  transformed  gender  roles.  Women  face  the  burden  of 
caring  and  providing  for  the  family,  while  contributing  to  community  life  in  welfare  centers  or 
refugee  camps.  Conflict-related  disability,  often  of  males,  has  placed  additional  burdens  on 
women  and  other  family  members.  Family  and  household  structures  have  been  recast,  with 
many families forming one household, households headed by one person (female and male), or 
families composed of grandparents and grandchildren. The conflict left many widows who took 
on the role of head of household, combining the traditional roles of breadwinner and caregiver. 
The tsunami has reversed this trend and left a large number of households headed by men. 
 
D. 
 
18. 
ADB has considerable experience in implementing emergency reconstruction through its 
ongoing  projects  in  conflict-affected  areas.  These  projects  have  been  recognized  for  their 
(i) preparedness  to  respond  quickly  and  flexibly;  (ii) a  bottom-up  approach  to  subproject 
selection; (iii) balanced treatment of sectors, geographic areas, and ethnic groups; (iv) a focus 
on  restoring  facilities;  (v) prompt  supervision  by  ADB  during  implementation,  as  the  projects 
place  a  heavy  burden  on  executing  and  implementing  agency  staff;  (vi) rapid  action  by  the 
Government; and (vii) close donor coordination.  
 
ADB’s  experience  has  yielded  the  following  lessons:  (i) participation  by  all  sections  of 
19. 
affected  communities, 
including  consultative  processes  and  social  mobilization,  needs 
assessments,  and  participatory  planning,  must  be  ensured  during  project  preparation  and 
implementation;  (ii) the  particular  needs  of  women,  households  headed  by  one  person,  the 
elderly,  and  the  disabled  must  be  addressed;  (iii) environmental  and  social  aspects  should  be 
considered  during  project  implementation,  even  though  the  need  for  rapid  response  may  not 
permit  detailed  treatment  of  these  issues  before  assistance is  approved;  (iv) arrangements  for

infrastructure  alone  reduces  project  benefits,  so  broader  issues  of  assisting  communities  and

during  implementation;  (vii) there  should  be  simple  prioritization  in  subproject  selection  and 
short implementation periods, but there must also be a balanced distribution of benefits among 
communities  and  affected  areas;  (viii) close  and  frequent  monitoring  is  needed  to  ensure

a result of the tsunami disaster.

Labour Organization, JBIC is providing a loan for the development of small and medium-sized 
enterprises, and ADB has extended a microfinance and microcredit facility. In addition, as a co-
chair of the needs assessment exercise, ADB has strongly promoted the adoption of common 
standards  and  policies  that  all  external  development  partners  should  adopt  in  designing  their 
interventions,  in  order  to  minimize  potential  for  conflict  and  social  tension.  The  role  of  the 
various partners in each sector is shown in Appendix 4.  
 
26. 
Separate  assistance  grants  from  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  are  being 
processed  to  provide  a  total  of  $4 million  to  Sri  Lanka  to  restore  and  create  line  drainage 
systems along tsunami-affected roads and to provide microfinance opportunity for post-tsunami 
utility connections at newly-built or repaired houses. Outreach programs will provide information 
to affected people on microfinance opportunities. These programs will be independent from, but 
complementary to, the projects described in this paper; separate Board approval will be sought 
for these assistance grants.

1. 

Component A: Legal Assistance, Governance and Anticorruption  

 
29. 
The destruction wrought by the tsunami has generated legal and documentary issues for 
tsunami-affected  people  and  the  Government,  and  the  generous  contributions  of  foreign 
assistance  have  raised  potential  governance  and  corruption  issues  for  the  government.    The 
Legal Assistance, Governance and Anticorruption Component seeks to address these issues. It 
will  provide  legal  assistance  to  tsunami-affected  victims  to  help  them  address  legal  and 
documentary issues arising from the tsunami. It will also establish a decentralized mechanism 
for  tsunami  victims  for  private  dispute  resolution  and  grievance  review  against  public  officials. 
Three proposals for achieving this end are currently under discussion with the government, and 
it is most likely to involve a combination of these mechanisms. They are establishing (a) tsunami 
mediation  boards  to  address  tsunami  related  disputes  and  grievances,  based  on  existing  and 
working  statutory  mediation  boards;  (b)  a  decentralized  office  of  tsunami  ombudsmen,  or  an 
extension of the work of the existing Ombudsmen to deal with grievances against public officials 
relating  to  the  tsunami;  and/or  (c)  establishing  a  unit  within  the  administrative  division  of  Sri 
Lanka’s  Bribery  and  Corruption  Commission,  to  concentrate  on  detecting,  investigating,  and 
otherwise  responding  to  corruption  in  tsunami-assistance.  In  addition,  training  and  awareness 
workshops  will  be  conducted  for  judges,  magistrates,  district  officials,  and  the  public  on  the 
potential tsunami or disaster emergency related legal issues, disputes or cases that are likely to 
arise. This will include the tsunami legislative framework that is currently under consideration for 
making special provision for persons and property affected by the tsunami.  
 
30. 
The  replacement  of  birth,  death,  and  marriage  certificates,  and  property  titles,  and 
identification  cards  will  be  supported.  Methods  used  for  replacing  documents  will  include 
supporting the collection and coordination of data by the relevant departments and offices, and 
through  modernizing  computer  collection  of  such  data;  transforming  manual  central  record 
keeping  at  the  Registrar  General’s  department  and  the  Department  of  the  Registration  of 
Persons  into  computerized  record  keeping,  and  facilitating  the  connectivity,  coordination  and 
networking  of  such  information.  This  will  facilitate  location  of  records  lost  by  tsunami  victims, 
and  hence  the  reissue  of  relevant  certificates  and  cards.  In  the  process  of  data  collection, 
tsunami  victim  identity  cards  will  be  provided  so  as  to  reduce  the  extent  false  claims  for 
assistance  can  be  made.  TAARP  will  also  support  transparency  of  tsunami  and  emergency 
assistance, through the Office of the President by supporting the publication in Sinhala, Tamil, 
and English, on the internet and in government newspapers, of (i) modes of tsunami assistance 
from  development  partners  and  NGOs,  (ii)  contract  and  procurement  details  in  relation  to 
tsunami-assistance,  (iii) any  proposed  laws,  bills,  or  policy relating  to  tsunami  assistance,  and 
(iv) Sri Lanka’s assistance to tsunami-affected people.  
 
31. Finally, the MOFP will be assisted to ensure good governance in NGO provision of tsunami 
assistance  by  supporting  the  development  of  guidelines  or  regulations  on  NGO  governance, 
accountability,  transparency,  and  registration  in  the  provision  of  tsunami  assistance.  An 
extensive description of these components is provided in Appendix 7.  
 

 2. 

Component B: North East Coastal Community Development 

 
32. 
Coastal  communities  in  the  districts  of  Jaffna,  Mullaittivu,  Kilinochchi,  Trincomalee, 
Batticaloa  and  Ampara  that  were  affected  by  the  tsunami  will  receive  support  under  this 
component.  Communities  that  have  been  affected  by  the  tsunami  in  terms  of  loss  of  life, 
destruction of assets, and disruption of livelihoods will be identified for support. Communities—
i.e.,  Grama  Niladhari  divisions  (footnote 7)—that  meet  the  criteria  will  receive  support  for: 
(i) construction  of  small-scale  community  infrastructure;  (ii) livelihood  development  activities; 
and  (iii) community  development  planning  and  coordination  at  the  local  authority  level.  In 
addition, this component will support restoration and sustainable management of natural habitat 
damaged during the tsunami and support coastal resource planning and management at district 
and provincial levels.  
 
33. 
Infrastructure.  Small-scale  community  infrastructure  could  include  minor  roads, 
culverts,  drains,  small-scale  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities,  simple  solid  waste 
management  schemes,  community  buildings  and  market  and/or  auction  halls.  Livelihood 
support interventions will consist of advisory services to identify and develop suitable livelihood 
options  (including  small  enterprises),  skills  development,  and  transfer  of  technology.  These 
advisory  services  will  be  linked  with  microcredit  provided  under  component  G.  All  these 
activities will need to be coordinated at the local authority level, so support for such coordination 
and planning will be provided under this component.  
 
34. 
Coastal  Zone  Planning.  The  tsunami  highlighted  the  importance  of  coastal  zone 
planning  in  averting  or  at  least  reducing  the  impact  of  natural  disasters.  TAARP  will  support 
coastal  zone  planning  that  takes  into  account  existing  natural  habitats  and  land  use  patterns. 
The  planning  process  will  be  participatory,  with  coordination  at  division,  district,  and  provincial 
levels, and eventual integration with the National Coastal Zone Management Plan.  
 
Natural  Resources.  Restoration  of  degraded  or  destroyed  natural  habitats  will  be 
35. 
undertaken through a community-based process. TAARP will support restoration of such areas 
and  concurrently  develop  livelihood  or  supplementary  income  generating  activities  that  will 
benefit  adjacent  communities  and  thereby  ensure  sustainable  management  of  the  natural 
habitat.  
 

3. 

Component C: Road Rehabilitation and Reconstruction 

 
National  Roads.  Subprojects  will  rehabilitate,  reconstruct,  or  improve  road  links 
36. 
damaged by the tsunami and improve the transport network overall. Among other benefits, this 
will improve the response to disasters. Access along tsunami-affected coastal roads has been 
restored,  albeit  through  temporary  repairs.  However,  the  road  resurfacing  and  embankment 
restorations  that  have  been  carried  out  are  not  anticipated  to  last  beyond  the  next  monsoon 
season. Tsunami-affected roads will be rebuilt according to national standards for each class of 
road. Road works will include reconstruction of previously-surfaced roads and drainage, location 
and  removal  of  mines  and  unexploded  ordnance,  repair  or  replacement  of  bridges  as 
necessary, and a review of “black-spot” or accident-prone areas so safety improvements can be 
incorporated  into  civil  works.  Road  works  will  be  designed  to  improve  roads  and  make  them 
more  resistant  to  expected  coastal  weather  and  drainage  patterns.  Road  shoulders  will  be 
paved where possible to provide better access and safer conditions for cyclists and pedestrians. 
About 300 kilometers (km) of major coastal road links (class A and B) in tsunami-affected areas 
in the South and North East of Sri Lanka will be rebuilt.

Component D: Water Supply and Sanitation 

 
Drinking  water  supply  and  sanitation  schemes  in  Hambantota,  Batticaloa  and  Muttur

districts  (which  were  affected  by  the  tsunami)  will  be  repaired  and  expanded.  Subprojects  will

Component E: Southern Province Reconstruction 

 
40. 
Infrastructure. Subprojects in component E will restore livelihoods by creating jobs for 
locally-based skilled and unskilled labor and reconstructing community and urban infrastructure, 
which  could  include  local  government  roads,  culverts,  drains,  small-scale  water  supply  and 
sanitation  facilities,  simple  solid  waste  management  schemes,  village  markets  (polas), 
ayurvedic  (traditional  medicine)  dispensaries,  children’s  parks,  playgrounds,  community 
buildings and rest houses, market and/or auction halls. Training for new employment skills will 
be offered. Physical infrastructure and buildings, such as public libraries, courts, police stations, 
prisons,  and  district  registry  offices  needed  to  reestablish  an  effective  law  and  public 
administration  system  will  also  be  reconstructed.  Designs  for  reconstructed  buildings  will

through  the  subproject  selection  process  described  in  Appendix 6.  TAARP  will  also  support 
community development planning and coordination at the local authority level.  
 
Shelter.  Nearly  100,000  houses  were  destroyed  by  the  tsunami.  Other  donors  have

made  significant  commitments  for  the  reconstruction  of  damaged  or  destroyed  housing  in 
tsunami-affected  areas.  However,  if  demands  remain  unmet,  this  component  will  construct

infrastructure subprojects.

Component F: Coastal Resources Management 

 
Subprojects  will  repair  damage  done  to  coastal  stabilization  structures  and  harbor 
42. 
breakwaters,  extend  such  structures,  identify  additional  sites  for  improvements,  and  provide 
small fishing boat anchorages and fisheries-related ancillary units, such as boat-building yards, 

 10 

 
 

net repair sheds, or cold-storage facilities, in the Southern and Western provinces. Subprojects 
will  also  provide  enhanced  coastal  protection  and  environmental  management  along  the 
affected coasts by reestablishing green zones or green belts through intensive forestation with

Component G: Rural Finance  

 
43. 
Immediate support is needed so affected people can rebuild their lives and regain their 
dignity,  and  so  local  economies  can  be  revived.  This  component  will  include  (i) restoring 
livelihoods  of  affected  poor  households  or  groups  affected  by  the  tsunami  by  providing 
immediate  access  to  noncommercial  microcredit,  (ii) supporting  microenterprise  and  skills 
training, (iii) mitigating risk by insuring affected households or individuals that receive assistance 
under this component through life and property insurance schemes, and (iv) providing support 
for  operational  costs  and  rebuilding  of  physical  assets  of  microfinance  institutions  in  remote 
areas.  
 
44. 
A  major  change  in  implementation  arrangements  for  the  Rural  Finance  Sector 
Development Program13 (RFSDP) was approved by ADB Vice President (Operations Group 1) 
on  23  February  2005  to  provide  microcredit  will  be  provided  to  certain  classes  of  tsunami 
affected  people.  TAARP  will  provide  microcredit  on  similar  but  broader  terms  to  the  revised 
arrangements  to  the  tsunami-affected  people  who  need  them  most—low-income  households, 
which  comprise  about  75%  of  all  affected  households.  The  interest  rate  charged  will  be 
noncommercial  and  in  line  with  the  Central  Bank  of  Sri  Lanka  directive  for  loans  to  tsunami-
affected  persons.  These  loans,  together  with  rescheduling  of  existing  debts,  will  enable  more 
money  to  be  spent  on  household  needs.  Loans  to  affected  households  will  be  limited  to 
Rs100,000 (approximately $1,000) to ensure a focus on poor households. The grant portion of 
this component will be used to finance items (ii) to (v) above and detailed during inception.

57. 
Sri Lanka is a tsunami-affected country beginning rehabilitation and reconstruction. It is 
also recovering from conflict and making the transition to peace and stability. The disaster policy 
modifies the prevailing ADF lending terms approved by the ADB Board so they are appropriate 
for  disaster,  emergency,  and  post-conflict  assistance.21  ADB  has  approved  the  use  of  such 
terms in Bangladesh for the Emergency Flood Damage Rehabilitation Project (January 2005), in

under  ADB's  Disaster  Policy  and  the  same  as  those  of  the  Approved  Loans.  The  term  of  the 
loan will be 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with a repayment of principal at 2% 
per  year  for  the  first  10  years  after  the  grace  period  and  4%  a  year  thereafter,  to  be  paid 
semiannually, with an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum.

Justification for Special Loan Terms and Grants 

1. 

ADF Loan  

 
114.  Sri  Lanka  is  recovering  from  conflict  and  making  the  transition  to  peace  and  stability. 
ADB's disaster policy modifies the prevailing ADF lending terms approved by the ADB Board so 
they  are  appropriate  for  disaster,  emergency,  and  post-conflict  assistance.  The  disaster  policy 
covers  post-conflict  assistance  and  provides  that  emergency  assistance  loans  are  to  cover 
short-term  immediate  needs  including  rehabilitation  of  priority  water,  transport,  and  other 
infrastructure,  to  regenerate  livelihoods  and  boost  productivity,  and  revitalize  social  services, 
among  other  things  (footnote  9).  The  ADF  loan  would  be  extended  to  Sri  Lanka  to  cover  a 
portion  of  the  remaining  unfunded  immediate  term  needs  identified  in  the  2003  post-conflict 
needs  assessment  and  still  unmet  (refer  to  paragraph  12  for  the  description  of  these  needs), 
livelihoods,  boosting 
including 

rehabilitation  of  priority 

regeneration  of 

infrastructure,

productivity, and revitalizing social services. It is proposed that the loan from ADF be made on 
concessional  terms  permitted  under  ADB's  disaster  policy,  and  the  same  as  the  Approved 
Loans.  The  term  of  the  loan  will  be  40  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  10  years,  with  a 
repayment of principal at 2% per year for the first 10 years after the grace period and 4% a year 
thereafter, to be paid semiannually, with an interest charge at the rate of 1% per annum.  
 

2. 

ADF Grant 

 
115.  The  Board  of  Governors  of  ADB  resolved  to  establish  a  new  grant  program  during  the 
Asian Development Fund IX Annual Meeting, under the ADF IX resolution42. Donors agreed that 
ADF  grants  could  be  used  to  assist  poor  countries  make  the  transition  from  post-conflict  to 
peace and stability, as well as for HIV/AIDS prevention. Sri Lanka was identified as one of the 
post-conflict countries and eligible for ADF grants43. The post-conflict situation in the North East 
of  Sri  Lanka  qualifies  Sri  Lanka  for  such  ADF  grant  funding.  In  addition,  the  HIV/AIDS 
subcomponent  qualifies  for  ADF  grant  financing,  although,  as  it  is  not  a  large  subcomponent, 
will be financed through the post-conflict country allocation of the ADF grant.

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management 

 
116.  NECORD-II will be implemented using the same process approach and implementation 
arrangements  as  NECORD  that  are  already  working  successfully.  NECORD’s  PMU  in 
Trincomalee will be strengthened and maintained for the duration of NECORD-II. The PMU will 
be headed by the project director, who will have direct responsibility for implementing NECORD-
II, through the existing provincial and central government sector agencies, and for ensuring that 
the  essential  balances  among  communities  are  monitored  and  maintained.  The  PMU  will 
manage  and  coordinate  subprojects  through  existing  structures  and  procedures  at  provincial, 
district, and division levels. The PMU will act as the secretariat for NPCC and PPCC. The PMU 
may  engage  suitably  qualified  and  acceptable  international  and  domestic  NGOs  to  manage 
specific NECORD-II activities in accordance with procedures acceptable to ADB. District project 
management units (DPMUs) established in each district under NECORD will continue to closely 
monitor  the  implementation  of  district  subprojects  and  report  to  the  PMU.  A  deputy  project 
director,  who  will  directly  implement  smaller-scale  subprojects  at  the  district  and  divisional 
levels, will head each DPMU. 
 
117.  Given the complexity and sensitivity of NECORD-II and the need for close coordination 
with the actors in the North East—the Government, LTTE, external assistance agencies, NGOs, 
and others—NECORD-II will be administered through the ADB Resident Mission in Colombo.  
 

2.

across  all  the  conflict-affected  districts—taking  into  account  geographic  and  sector  balances 
along  with  the  ethnic  composition—to  maximize  benefits  in  the  affected  areas  and,  equally 
important,  to  not  contribute  to  the  intercommunal  tensions  that  led  to  the  conflict.  NECORD-II

3. 

Implementation Period 

 
119.  Like  TAARP,  NECORD-II  will  be  implemented  over  a  4-year  period.  This  period  is 
needed  because  of  the  geographic  distribution  and  extent  of  damage  caused  by  the  20-year 
conflict,  the  time  required  to  formulate  and  package  subprojects  and  civil  works  contracts,  the 
necessity for community consultation and mobilization, the potential need for clearance of mines 
and  unexploded  ordnance,  and  the  limitations  of  still  evolving  institutions.  Capacity  building  at 
the  various  implementing  departments  and  the  construction  industry  in  the  North  East  has 
begun—in part through the NECORD subprojects already completed—but the need for further 
capacity building remains. Contractor capacity has been strengthened in the North East through 
a series of construction and contracting seminars presented in 2004 by Deutsche Gesellschaft 
für  Technische  Zusammenarbeit  (GTZ)  and  ADB.  Equally  important,  the  conflict  destroyed 
much  of  the  human  capacity  in  the  area,  in  the  Government,  NGOs,  and  the  private  sector. 
NECORD-II will continue the essential but time- and resource-consuming task of rebuilding this 
capacity.  The  existing  national  project  coordinating  committee  and  provincial  project 
coordinating  committee  will  continue  to  operate  under  NECORD-II.  The  scheduled  completion 
date is 30 June 2009, the same as for TAARP (Appendix 11).

 5. 

Procurement of Civil Works and Equipment 

 
123.  Procurement of goods and services under NECORD-II will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and the Government’s tender procedures acceptable to 
ADB.  ADB’s  disaster  policy  permits  flexible  interpretation  of  these  guidelines,  so  that  project 
activities can start promptly.  
 
124.  For civil works contracts with estimated values greater than $5 million, procurement will 
be  in  accordance  with  international  competitive  bidding  procedures.  For  contracts  with 
estimated  values  of  $5 million  and  below,  procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  local 
competitive  bidding  (LCB)  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB.  Local  procurement  will  be  the 
preferred  mode  for  most  NECORD-II  activities  because  of  the  relatively  short  implementation 
period, the relatively small size of most contract packages, the wide geographic spread of the 
subproject  sites,  and  the  need  for  local  awareness  of  security  and  other  frequently  changing 
matters relevant to the North East. Contracts with estimated values less than $100,000 will be 
procured under LCB using post-facto approval procedures, as is currently typical for NECORD. 
LCB civil works procurement will include single-stage, two-envelope procedures where relevant, 
and bidding periods of at least 21 days.  
 
125.  Equipment and materials will be procured under international competitive bidding where 
the  estimated  cost  is  more  than  $500,000  equivalent,  by  international  shopping  where  the 
estimated  cost  is  between  $300,000  and  $500,000  equivalent,  and  through  local  procurement 
procedures acceptable to ADB where the estimated cost is $300,000 equivalent or less. Minor 
items costing less than $100,000 equivalent may be procured through direct purchase.  
 
126.  The  Government  has  requested  ADB’s  approval  of  advance  action  for  procurement  of 
civil  works,  including  inviting  and  receiving  bids  for  contracts,  for  subprojects  that  might  be 
approved for implementation prior to loan effectiveness. The Government has been advised that 
ADB’s approval of advance action would not commit ADB to financing NECORD-II.

127.  The  existing  consultants  for  NECORD,  who  are  providing  support  for  procurement, 
contract  management,  and  training,  will  extend  their  services  through direct  selection  to  cover 
the  additional  requirements  of  NECORD-II.  For  new  services,  primarily  for  accounting  and 
general  engineering,  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the 
engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  Consultants  will  be  provided  individually  and  through

V. 

PROJECTS’ BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

Projects’ Benefits and Impacts 

 
A. 
 
134.  The  vast  majority  of  the  people  directly  affected  by  the  tsunami  disaster  were  at  the 
lower  end  of  the  economic  scale,44  partly  because  the  districts  affected  tended  to  have  high 
levels of poverty at the time of the disaster and partly because people who lived in substandard 
housing were less able to resist the onslaught of the waves. In the conflict-affected North East, 
poverty  levels  are  estimated  to  be  60%–90%,  much  higher  than  in  the  rest  of  the  country, 
although  there  are  gaps  in  government  surveys  for  much  of  the  area.  For  both  tsunami-  and 
conflict-affected  people,  basic  socioeconomic  facilities  need  to  be  restored  if  affected 
communities  are  to  recover  and  begin  the  long  climb  back  to  normalcy.  A  summary  poverty 
reduction and social strategy is provided as Appendix 18.  
 
135.  These projects together will address the urgent needs of about 3 million people, among 
which the physically disabled, single heads of households and children feature significantly. By 
restoring sectors that form the backbone of the economy in the affected areas, NECORD-II will 
help  to  rebuild  affected  communities,  and  to  stabilize  the  economic  base  of  local  populations, 
helping people to move from dependency on government support to sustainable livelihoods.  
 
136.  TAARP  and  NECORD-II  focus  on  restoring  preexisting  facilities,  allowing  for  technical 
improvements  and  future  demand,  based  on  a  least-cost  approach.  TAARP  also  aims  to 
strengthen the coastal environment. Taking into consideration the long years of neglect, project 
interventions focus not only on the physical rehabilitation of damaged infrastructure but also on 
the  restoration  of  the  physical  and  institutional  arrangements  for  legal,  administrative  and 
technical services.  
 
137.  Creating an environment that is conducive for vulnerable and marginalized groups in the 
conflict- and tsunami-affected areas to participate in reconstruction activities is an urgent need. 
Conflict widows, wives of the “disappeared,” single heads of households, and widowers have to 
deal  with  transformations  in  social  roles  that  place  new  burdens  on  them.  Helping  them  to 
become  economically  independent  and  to  improve  the  well-being  of  their  families  involves 
reduce existing inequalities and discrimination. To this end, a gender action plan is presented in 
Appendix 19.

financial 
sustainability  criteria,  and,  as  both  projects  involve  replacing  old,  and  in  some  cases, 
depreciated  assets,  there  is  a  possibility  of  incremental  operations  and  maintenance  savings. 
TAARP and NECORD-II are therefore deemed to be financially sustainable.  
 
140. 
In  responding  to  the  tsunami,  Sri  Lanka’s  financial  and  human  capacities  are  being 
strained.  The  volume  and  scale  of  tsunami-related  foreign  assistance  being  provided  to  Sri 
Lanka  could  lead  to  governance,  corruption,  and  administration  of  justice  issues.  The  size  of 
public  and  private  contributions  to  Sri  Lanka  may  exceed  the  current  capacity  of  the 
Government’s  public  administration  and  justice  systems  to  manage  the  funds,  leaving 
opportunities for individuals and public officials to take advantage of the large influx of funds and 
vulnerable people.  
 
141.  Factors mitigating governance and corruption risks include detailed subproject selection 
criteria, transparent implementation and monitoring mechanisms, specific financial controls and 
regular  and  random  audits.  Additional  budget  provisions  for  supervision  and  monitoring, 
particularly  by  Resident  Mission  staff  will  also  serve  to  strengthen  governance  controls.  In 
addition,  the  Government’s  capacity  for  procurement,  financial  management,  supervision  and 
monitoring has been assessed and will be further strengthened through TAARP. In addition to 
the usual submission of annual audited reports and related financial statements to ADB, regular 
and random supervision and monitoring reviews will be undertaken. Provision has been made in 
both  projects  for  independent  annual  financial  audits  and  regular  performance  audits.  The 
Resident Mission is also strengthening its ability to supervise and provide guidance and training 
to PMUs. A decentralized system of private dispute resolution, and public grievance review, will 
be  established  under  TAARP  to  investigate  and  resolve  any  private  disputes  or  claims  of 
impropriety against public officials relating to tsunami assistance. Manual systems of document 
storage  and  retrieval  for  personal  identity  documents  will  be  modernized  to  minimize  risks  of 
false claims and corruption. Publication of tsunami assistance, procurement, and tsunami policy 
matters in all three languages (Sinhala, Tamil and English), in government newspapers and on 
a  web-site,  will  provide  the  public  with  information  and  so  improve  transparency  and 
accountability.  Legal  assistance  will be  provided  to  tsunami-affected  people  to  enable  them  to 
avail of their legal entitlements for good governance, and to minimize disputes.  
 
142.  Provision of significant assistance to tsunami-affected people can produce tensions if it 
is perceived that different parts of the country or ethnic groups are receiving more than their fair 
share of reconstruction funds, or if other people who are in poverty or internally displaced feel 
they  are  being  forgotten.  As  a  result,  social  tensions  and  conflict  can  actually  increase, 
undermining implementation of reconstruction.  

 143.  The  peace  and  conflict  impact  assessment  is  available  as  Supplementary  Appendix D. 
By fitting in the general framework of the national reconstruction plan, both projects will ensure 
that  overall  allocation  of  funds  to  the  affected  areas  follows  reconstruction  needs  and  that  the 
same  criteria  and  policies  are  applied  to  tsunami-  and  conflict-affected  areas.  In  addition, 
subproject  selection  will  ensure  that  the  beneficial  outcomes  are  shared  equitably  among  the 
major ethnic groups and across the target area. Both projects will make a positive contribution 
to strengthening the socioeconomic fabric of the affected areas by rebuilding key infrastructure. 
Equity  and  conflict  resolution  will  be  pursued  through  (i) selection  of  communities  and 
subprojects to ensure an ethnic balance that reasonably reflects the general ethnic composition 
of  the  affected  areas;  (ii) consultation  with  all  major  stakeholders  regarding  the  final  choice  of 
subprojects;  and  (iii) consistent  application  of  the  principle  of  subsidiarity,  to  ensure  that 
recovery decisions are taken as close as possible to the affected populations, with their active 
involvement as stakeholders in the process.  
 
144.  The bureaucratic application of normal implementation procedures could result in delays 
in the rehabilitation and reconstruction of tsunami-affected areas. Disputes relating to property 
rights  caused  by  loss  of  title  documents,  shifting  of  shorelines,  occupation  of  private  lands  by 
squatters,  elimination  of  property  boundaries,  and  resettlement  of  displaced  people  may  also 
cause delays.  
 
145.  To  address  these  risks,  ADB  is  assisting  the  National  Procurement  Agency  to  simplify 
the  emergency  procurement  guidelines  and  the  procurement  guidelines  for  Sri  Lanka.  TAARP 
will engage consultants to support procurement and the planning and evaluation of subprojects, 
as requested by the Government. Existing PMUs will be used to implement the project, avoiding 
the time needed to establish new ones. They will be strengthened by adding capacity to ensure 
no  delays  in  implementation  or  processing  of  payments.  Retroactive  financing  has  been 
included  so  urgent  activities  can  be  funded.  The  legal  assistance  and  governance  measures 
mentioned above will minimize the risk of legal and documentary related disputes.  
 
146.  Another  risk  is  that,  once  a  period  of  time  has  passed,  the  national  Government  or 
provincial  and  local  governments  may  not  maintain  sufficient  commitment  to  implement  both 
projects in an efficient and timely manner.  
 
147.  The Government has established TAFREN, involving high-caliber members from private 
and public sectors. It is preparing a bill to be submitted to parliament to transform TAFREN into 
an Authority that will coordinate reconstruction over a 3 to 5 year period. Reconstruction under 
TAARP  will  be  undertaken  within  this  national  framework,  while  special  mechanisms  and 
agreements are being developed for affected districts in the North East, to ensure participation 
and commitment by all stakeholders.  
 
148.  Competition  among  donors  offering  assistance  and  insufficient  coordination  in  the 
provision of assistance could lead to gaps or overlaps in sector or geographic coverage, poor 
delivery of needed benefits to tsunami-affected people, or the application of different policies or 
standards in different areas.  
 
149.  A  good  climate  for  cooperation  has  been  established  through  the  tsunami  needs 
assessment.  In  the  second  phase  of  the  assessment,  which  is  focusing  on  implementation 
mechanisms  and  coordination,  the  steering  group  has  been  expanded  to  include  bilateral 
development partners, NGOs, and the private sector. While coordinating the international NGOs 
that have raised large cash contributions will be a challenge, a good basis for cooperation has 
been  laid.  The  Government  is  leading  the  second  phase  of  the  needs  assessment,  and  has

indicated its intention to play a strong role in coordination, including listing all significant projects 
on the TAFREN website. ADB, JBIC, and the World Bank are working closely together, taking 
turns to chair reconstruction-related meetings. ADB and the World Bank have explicitly declared 
that they will make their reconstruction operations flexible, in order to play a “gap-filling” role to 
complement other development partners.  
 
150.  Price  escalation  is  a  risk.  An  increase  in  the  demand  for  construction  materials  in  an 
already  constrained  supply  environment  could  lead  to  price  escalation  and  dramatically  affect 
the amount of reconstruction that can be carried out under either project. An adequate supply of 
construction  materials  (sand,  cement,  reinforcing  steel)  must  be  readily  accessible  to  the 
construction industry, in particular in the North East, where there is already a large construction 
program underway.  
 
151.  The  possibility  of  rising  prices  has  been  raised  in  a  number  of  meetings  with  the 
Government,  and  mitigating  measures  are  being  designed.  Selective  import  liberalization  and 
spreading  implementation  over  a  longer  period  (up  to  4  years,  depending  on  urgency  of 
interventions) will help to smooth out pressures on supply.

GUIDING PRINCIPLES OF THE RECOVERY STRATEGY 

 
The  allocation  of  domestic  and  international  resources  should  be  strictly  guided  by  the 
1. 
identified  needs  and 
local  priorities,  without  political,  religious,  ethnic,  or  gender 
discrimination.  The  recovery  strategy  should  take  into  account  the  extent  of  progress  in  Sri 
Lanka  since  the  signing  of  the  cease-fire  agreement,  after  a  long  conflict,  and  seek  to 
strengthen  the  peace  process.  Reconstruction  interventions  should  build  confidence  between 
different  actors  in  the  process.  Reconstruction  should  similarly  be  sensitive  to  the  impact  on 
neighboring but unaffected communities.  
 
2. 
The  strategy  should  be  based  on  the  principle  of  subsidiarity:  each  reconstruction 
activity should be designed and implemented at the lowest competent tier of government. While 
the  central  Government  should  lead  in  setting  standards,  policies,  and  principles,  subsidiarity 
allows  for  locally  appropriate  solutions  and  enables  a  range  of  subnational  structures  and 
organizations  to  be  directly  engaged  in  the  process.  The  recovery  plan  (which  should  be 
disaggregated  to  district  level)  will  provide  for  capacity  building  and  strengthening  at  various 
levels  of  governance,  but  especially  in  the  districts  and  pradeshiya  sabhas,1  as  well  as  local 
civil-society organizations.  
 
3. 
The  recovery  strategy  should  focus  on  the  victims’  medium-  and  long-term  needs. 
Therefore, enhanced and solid consultation with affected communities and stakeholders is 
essential, and communities should be empowered to make their own decisions during recovery 
and  participate  fully  in  reconstruction  activities.  All  interventions  need  to  respond  to  clearly 
identified and articulated needs of communities, respecting their religion, culture, structures, and 
customs.  This  is  especially  important  with  respect  to  the  policies  related  to  shelter  and 
relocation,  which  should  not  proceed  without  such  full  consultation.  Communities  should  be 
assisted  to  return  to  their  original  homes  as  swiftly  as  possible.  To  maximize  the  speed  of 
recovery, local capacities should be harnessed as far as possible.  
 
4. 
Better  communication  and  transparency  are  needed  in  decision  making  and 
implementation. Mechanisms should be strengthened to ensure access to information regarding 
policies, entitlements, and implementation procedures, and to permit more regular feedback to 
implementing  authorities,  as  well  as  grievance  redress.  Similarly,  mechanisms  to  ensure 
transparency  in  resource  use  and  comprehensive  accounting  need  to  be  enhanced,  at  the 
aggregate,  program,  and  beneficiary  levels,  accompanied  by  more  effective  monitoring  and 
evaluation  systems,  to  permit  a  full  accounting  to  Parliament,  development  partners,  civil 
society, and the affected communities of resources deployed from all sources. All parties should 
reaffirm their policy of zero tolerance for corruption in this joint effort.  
 
5. 
Reconstruction  processes  should  reduce  vulnerability  to  natural  hazards,  including 
floods,  cyclones,  and  landslides.  A  multi-hazard  risk  approach  should  be  used  during  the 
recovery  phase  to  ensure  that  communities  and  assets  are  less  vulnerable  to  impacts  of 
disasters,  while  balancing  the  social  costs  of  excessive  resettlement.  It  should  be  guided  by 
international standards and best practices in design and asset management.  
 
6. 
All the above considerations suggest a number of factors that will need to be built into 
the analysis of individual interventions. They should be analyzed for their potential impact on 
the  cease-fire  and  the  prospects  for  peace.  For  long-term  sustainability,  such  interventions 
should incorporate governance, gender sensitivity, environment, resettlement and land issues,

8. 
A coordinated approach is critical to ensure that the above principles are followed and 
to prevent duplication or overlap in activities. Development partners should minimize the burden 
on the overextended Government, not least by maximizing their own coordination. Coordination 
should not just be between Government and donors but involve all stakeholders, including civil

COORDINATION OF EXTERNAL ASSISTANCE FOR POST-TSUNAMI RECONSTRUCTION 

 
1. 
During  the  early  days  after  the  tsunami  struck  Sri  Lanka  on  26  December,  a  large 
amount of assistance was spontaneously offered by individuals, nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs), and the private sector. This included persons supplying food to and housing neighbors; 
corporations  taking  charge  of  organizing  and  supplying  camps  for  people  displaced  by  the 
tsunami,  and  domestic  and  international  NGOs  along  with  agencies  from  the  United  Nations 
(UN)  system  mobilizing  large  amounts  of  supplies,  food,  water,  and  other  necessities. 
Coordination  was  made  difficult  by  the  large  number  of  agencies  and  organizations  involved, 
and by size of the affected area. The UN system helped greatly in establishing the Center for 
National Operations, which coordinates the logistics and other dimensions of the relief effort.  
 
The  Government  issued  on  11  January  a  preliminary  assessment  of  the  casualties,

Interestingly, the three estimates were of the same order of magnitude, estimating total damage 
at $1.5 billion–$1.6 billion, more of it outside the southern and western provinces.  
 
The  next  steps  implemented  during  February  and  March  included  (i)  a  number  of 
3. 
consultations with all stakeholders to reconcile the different estimates on the basis of common 
technical criteria, so that the Government could issue a revised needs assessment acceptable 
to  all  parties;  (ii)  a  second  phase  of  district-level  consultations  carried  out  by  mixed  teams 
representing the Government, external development partners, and local stakeholders, to ensure 
a  consultative  process  in  designing  implementation  mechanisms  for  reconstruction;  and  (iii) 
enlargement  of  the  development  partner  group  to  include  bilateral  donors,  UN  agencies,  civil 
society, and the private sector. To facilitate interaction, a representative steering committee with 
about  10  members  meets  weekly  to  closely  supervise  the  continuing  needs  assessment  and 
identify issues that need to be urgently addressed by the Government, while a larger meeting of 
all  development  partners  takes  place  every  2  weeks.  A  lead  agency  in  the  international 
community  and  a  board  member  of  the  Task  Force  for  Rebuilding  the  Nation  (TAFREN) 
convene  sector-level  meetings  where  the  development  partners  and  relevant  government 
ministries  can  discuss  policy  issues,  refine  reconstruction  needs  estimates,  and  develop 
financing plans.

Coastal Zone Planning. The tsunami highlighted the importance of planning to avert or 
reduce  the  impact  of  natural  disasters  or,  as  more  often  encountered,  cyclonic  storms.  The 
Project  will  support  a  coastal  zone  planning  process,  taking  into  consideration  the  natural 
habitat and the need for coastal reservation zones. The planning process will be participatory, 
with  coordination  at  the  division,  district,  and  provincial  levels.  The  ultimate  outcome  of  this 
process will be a consolidation and incorporation of planning outputs with the National Coastal 
Zone Management Plan.  
 
C. 
 
13. 
Component  C  will  be  fully  funded  through  the  ATF.  Subprojects  will  rehabilitate, 
reconstruct, and improve road links damaged by the tsunami, and improve the transport network 
overall  to  improve  disaster  response.  Access  along  tsunami-affected  coastal  roads  has  been 
restored,  albeit 
resurfacing  and 
embankment  restorations  now  in  place  are  not  anticipated  to  last  beyond  the  next  monsoon 
season.  More  thorough  and  permanent  road  rebuilding  measures,  particularly  for  improved 
drainage,  are  necessary  to  protect  the  roadway  network  of  main  transport  links  and  feeder 
roads along the coastal belt, particularly against frequent high rains and potential flooding. The 
rehabilitation  of  strategic  road  links  in  the  North  East  will  improve  disaster-response  capacity 
and promote economic growth and community development.  
 
14. 
The  component  will  rebuild  approximately  300  kilometers  (km)  of  major  coastal  road 
links (classes A and B) in tsunami-affected areas, in the South and the North East. About 200 
km of damaged class-C, -D, and -E access roads in the Southern Province will be rebuilt and 
provided with improved drainage.  
 
15. 
Tsunami-affected roads will be rebuilt according to national standards for each class of 
road.  Measures  will  be  incorporated  into  the  designs  to  improve  performance  and  durability 
against  expected  coastal  weather  and  drainage  patterns. To  provide  better  access  for  cyclists 
and  pedestrians,  particularly  in  the  North  East,  shoulders  will  be  paved  where  possible.  The 
road works will include removal of mines and unexploded ordnance, reconstruction of previously 
surfaced roads, drainage improvements and clearing, and repair or replacement of bridges. As 
the  works  will  be  carried  out  within  the  existing  right-of-way,  neither  land  acquisition  nor 
resettlement are expected to be required.

SUBPROJECT SELECTION PROCESS 

 
1. 
The  North  East  Community  Restoration  and  Development  Project  (NECORD)  uses  a 
sector-style  process  approach  to  develop  individual  subprojects.  This  approach,  which  works 
well,  will  be  used  to  prepare  subprojects  under  component  B  (North  East  coastal  community 
development), component E (Southern Province reconstruction), and component H (NECORD-
Tsunami),  under  the  Tsunami-affected  Areas  Rebuilding  Project  (TAARP)  and  subprojects 
under the North East Community Restoration and Development Project II (NECORD-II).  
 
2. 
Subprojects  will  be  initially  conceived  by  beneficiaries,  nongovernment  organizations, 
government  departments,  or  newly  formed  village  rehabilitation  committees  to  restore 
community livelihoods and area infrastructure damaged or lost as a result of the tsunami or the 
decades-long  conflict.  These  subproject  proposals  will  be  first  presented  to  the  divisional 
rehabilitation  committee  (DRC)  present  in  the  affected  districts.  The  DRC  will  review  and 
evaluate  each  proposal  against  set  subproject  criteria.  If  approved,  the  proposal  will  be 
forwarded  to  the  district  rehabilitation  coordinating  committee  (DRCC)  or  its  equivalent,  which 
will  further  scrutinize  the  subproject.  The  district  project  management  unit  (DPMU)  will  help 
these  agencies  prepare  subproject  proposals  in  the  standard  formats  to  be  used  for  both 
projects.  
 
After  approval  by  the  DRCC,  the  DPMU  through  the  government  agent  or  district 
3. 
secretary will present the subproject to the respective project management units (PMUs), which 
will  review  each  subproject  in  detail,  to  ensure  that  the  subproject  (i)  addresses  the  overall 
scope of the project, (ii) is eligible under the general and subcomponent-related criteria, (iii) will 
not  create  any  problems  in  the  area,  (iv)  has  been  sufficiently  justified,  and  (v)  will  attain  the 
desired outputs and benefits. The PMUs will (i) perform a detailed review of the subproject cost 
estimate  and  implementation  schedule;  (ii)  verify  beneficiary  contribution;  (iii)  determine  if 
contractors  are  available  and  capable  of  performing  the  work;  (iv)  confirm  that  land  will  be 
available; and (v) investigate any gender, social, or environmental concerns.  
 
4. 
If the PMU finds that the subproject satisfies all the evaluation criteria, the proposal will 
be then forwarded to the provincial project coordinating committee (PPCC) and, 15 days before 
a  PPCC  meeting,  circulated  to  ADB  and  the  relevant  secretaries,  ministries,  provincial,  and 
district  heads  of  departments;  government  agents;  government  security  coordinators  (police, 
army);  nongovernment  organizations;  the  United  Nations  system;  and  any  other  development 
institution  implementing  projects  in  the  area  (World  Bank,  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation, etc.).  
 
5. 
The  PPCC,  chaired  by  the  chief  secretary,  typically  meets  every  2  months  to  present 
each  subproject  for  conditional  approval.  Attendees  at  the  PCC  include  ADB,  relevant  PMU 
staff,  government  agents,  district  deputy  project  directors,  and  representatives  from  national 
ministries.  Subprojects  not  approved  by  the  PPCC  will  be  returned  to  the  PMU  or  DPMU  for 
further clarification or justification. If a subproject is approved by the PPCC, the PMU will inform 
the proponent to develop the subproject to include the designs, bill of quantities, specifications, 
and  the  bid  documents.  The  final  subproject  proposal  will  then  be  forwarded  to  ADB  for 
approval.  Subprojects  not  approved  by  ADB  will  be  returned  to  the  PMU  for  clarification  or 
modifications  to  better  comply  with  criteria  set  forth  for  TAARP  or  NECORD-II  or  ADB 
guidelines.

SPECIAL FEATURES OF PROJECT DESIGN FOR GOOD GOVERNANCE  
AND ANTICORRUPTION MEASURES 

Governance and Corruption Risks  

 
1. 
The risks of weak governance and corruption in the Tsunami-affected Areas Rebuilding 
Project  (TAARP)  and  the  North  East  Community  Restoration  and  Development  Project  II 
(NECORD-II)  are  a  concern.  ADB’s  interventions  in  these  projects  seek  to  comprehensively 
address these risks and balance the need for expeditious processing of ADB’s assistance, while 
ensuring and maintaining the integrity of the post-tsunami and post-conflict reconstruction and 
rehabilitation programs through a number of special project design features.  
 
A. 
 
Ensuring  good  governance  and  anticorruption  measures  are  key  features  of  ADB’s 
2. 
poverty reduction strategy and are priorities in all ADB-financed projects. The volume and scale 
of foreign assistance now being contributed to Sri Lanka could lead to governance breakdown 
and weaknesses in the law and administration of justice system. The size of public donor and 
private  contributions  provide  opportunities  for  private  individuals  and  public  officials  to  take 
advantage of people made vulnerable by the tsunami. The loss of documents and records, such 
as  property  titles,  birth  certificates,  death  certificates,  and  identification  cards  make  such 
opportunities  even  more  likely.  Individuals  have  already  reportedly  assumed  multiple  personal 
identities to register for relief at more than one location. The final resolution of property disputes, 
and the award of custody of children can only be resolved in Sri Lankan courts, which is likely to 
encumber  a  legal  system  already  overburdened  with  delayed  cases,  and  may  exacerbate 
inadequacies.  
 
B. 
 
3. 
TAARP  and  NECORD-II  seek  to  confront  these  risks  with  a  series  of  measures  that 
emphasize  the  transparency,  participation,  and  accountability  required  under  the  disaster 
policy.1 
 

Governance and Anticorruption Strategies  

1. 

Accounting and Procurement  

 
4. 
Accounting  Capacity.  The  capacity  of  the  projects’  project  management  units  and 
district project management units to follow good accounting practices is being strengthened by 
hiring  more  accountants.  Accounting  training  will  be  provided  to  further  strengthen  capacity. 
Good financial practice supports sound management and governance.  
 
5. 
Procurement. ADB has been advising the National Procurement Agency on measures 
to  streamline  and  accelerate  procurement  without  sacrificing  transparency  and  competition. 
Consultant  support  will  be  provided  through  TAARP  to  continue  and  formalize  procedural 
improvements without compromising integrity.  
 

2. 

Supervision and Monitoring  

 
6. 
Supervision  and  Monitoring.  As  required  by  the  disaster  policy,  TAARP  and 
NECORD-II  provide  for  additional  supervision  and  monitoring.  Internal  regular  and  random 
supervision  and  monitoring  are  required.  Specific  requirements  for  community  participation  in

7. 
Audits. TAARP and NECORD-II provide for private sector financial auditors, in order to 
have audited accounts provided to ADB within 6 months of the end of the financial year rather 
than the usual 9 months. TAARP and NECORD II also provide for special and random financial 
and  performance  audits  to  ensure  that  finances  are  used  for  their  intended  purposes.  These 
include spot and random audits, and semiannual external performance audits, which have been 
included  within  the  project  costs.  As  required  by  the  disaster  policy,  TAARP  and  NECORD-II 
provide for a special post-completion audit to address governance, financial accountability, and 
transparency. These will be funded by the Government.

Identification Cards. TAARP will help the Government, through the Department of the

Participation 

 
10. 
Local  Stakeholders.  TAARP  and  NECORD-II  will  facilitate  an  extensive  consultative 
and participatory process in subproject selection, design, implementation, and monitoring. Local 
stakeholders are involved in subproject selection, preparation, and implementation. Civil-society 
organizations  (CSOs)  and  NGOs  will  be  represented  on  the  provincial  project  coordination 
committee that approves the selection of subprojects. Different CSOs and NGOs will be eligible 
to be engaged as performance monitors, and any CSO or NGO engaged in providing goods or 
services under each project will be subject to audit.  
 
11. 
Development  Partners.  ADB  has  coordinated  closely  with  other  donors,  including  the 
World Bank, JBIC, and other bilateral partners, international organizations, including the United

Accountability 

 
12. 
Legal  Facilitation  and  Assistance.  TAARP  will  establish  a  centrally  coordinated, 
decentralized  system  for  providing  legal  assistance  to  tsunami-affected  people  to  ensure  that 
they can obtain lost documents, and are aware of the avenues for resolving family, custody, and 
property disputes resulting from the tsunami.  
 
Corruption Sanctioning. Under TAARP, and NECORD II, the Government has agreed 
13. 
to  quickly  sanction  private  individuals,  entities,  or  public  officials  who  take  or  attempt  to  take 
advantage of donor funds or the vulnerability of tsunami-affected people, in accordance with the 
Government’s policy of zero tolerance for corruption specifically in tsunami-related activities.  
 
14. 
Bribery and Corruption Commission. Under TAARP, the Government has agreed to 
establish  a  division  within  the  administrative  division  of  Sri  Lanka’s  Bribery  and  Corruption 
Commission,  to  concentrate  on  the  detection,  investigation,  and  response  to  tsunami-related 
corruption.

support  either  the  extension  of  the  existing  ombudsmen’s  role  to  cover  grievances  against 
public  officials  related  to  the  tsunami,  or  establish  a  decentralized  office  of  the  tsunami 
ombudsmen to do so, if requested by the Government.  
 
16.  Mediation Boards. TAARP would support a decentralized system of dispute resolution 
in tsunami-affected areas to deal with the anticipated increase in tsunami-related disputes. It will 
settle private disputes and may deal with citizen grievance against governments.  
 
17.  Modernization and Streamlining of Government Manual Record-keeping Systems. 
TAARP  supports  the  computer  automation  of  manual  systems  of  tsunami-related  information, 
thus increasing reliability and predictability of access to such information, limiting the extent to 
which the system can be manipulated for false claims for assistance, and increasing the extent 
tsunami affected people can claim public accountability for administration of records.
