2. 
The  proposed  projects  will  support  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka  in  the  recovery, 
reconstruction,  and  rehabilitation  process in  tsunami-affected  areas  nationwide  and  in  conflict-
affected  areas  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces.  The  recovery  and  rebuilding  process 
involves  the  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of  housing,  health  facilities,  schools,  water 
supplies,  irrigation  facilities,  roads,  coastal  structures,  fisheries  infrastructure,  government 
offices,  and  institutional  infrastructure.  Most  of  the  works  associated  with  rebuilding  the  above 
will  occur  on  preexisting  sites.  However,  some  rebuilding  in  the  course  of  either  project  might 
take place on government land or land acquired under the Land Acquisition Act.  
 
3. 
Damage caused by the tsunami on individual properties and livelihoods has exacerbated 
the damage caused by ethnic conflicts in some locations in the Northern and Eastern provinces. 
According to the initial needs assessments,1 the tsunami has destroyed about 100,000 houses, 
and partially damaged over 46,000 houses. Pre-tsunami ethnic conflicts had damaged over the 
50,000  houses  in  the  conflict-affected  areas.2  The  tsunami-affected  people  live  in  temporary 
camps.  The  Government’s  initiative  for  the  tsunami-affected  people  is  to  provide  (i)  livelihood 
grant  to  restart  livelihoods,  (ii)  a  housing  grant  and  loan  to  rebuild  the  destroyed  or  damaged 
house,  and  (iii)  a  plot  of  land  for  those  who  are  relocated.  The  Tsunami-affected  Areas 
Rebuilding  Project  (TAARP)  will  assist 
tsunami-affected 
households  in  situ—to  their  original  places  of  residence—through  cash  grants  in  accordance 
with  current  tsunami  housing  reconstruction  policy  for  rebuilding  their  shelter.  As  part  of  the 
community  development  subcomponents  under  the  TAARP,  assistance  will  be  provided  to 
households  for  assistance  in  restarting  their  livelihoods.  TAARP  will  rebuild  damaged  basic, 
community,  and  institutional  infrastructure  in  the  tsunami-affected  areas.  Through  the  North 
East  Community  Restoration  and  Development  Project  II  (NECORD-II),  the  Government  will 
reconstruct damaged in conflict-affected areas, assist the rehabilitation of basic needs such as 
health,  education,  irrigation,  agriculture,  replace  damaged  or  destroyed  shelter  in  situ,  and 
rebuild community infrastructure and income-generating programs.

Project Components with Resettlement Impacts  

Combined,  the  projects  will  assist  the  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  of  about  7,000 
5. 
houses, enabling some tsunami-affected households to return to their original residences. The 
beneficiary selection and housing grants will be in accordance with the Government’s policy3 on 
tsunami  reconstruction.  The  housing  program  will  be  supplemented  by  the  programs  of  basic 
social  infrastructures,  livelihood  improvement,  and  gender  development.  Social  infrastructure 
includes the rebuilding of damaged roads, coastal structures, and fisheries harbors.  
 
B. 
 
6. 
Housing.  To  the  extent  possible,  the  Government  will  assist  the  tsunami-affected 
households  to  rebuild  their  dwellings,  where  they  existed  when  the  tsunami  hit  them  in 
December 2004. The housing program is of two components: a cash grant and access to easy-
term  loans.4  Each  tsunami-affected  household  at  eligible  locations  will  receive  a  phased 
payment of a cash grant (different grants for fully damaged and partially damaged houses), and 
an  additional  housing  loan.  The  timing,  pace,  content,  and  extent  of  house  rebuilding  will  be 
managed  by  the  household  with  the  assistance  of  civil-society  organizations  (CSOs)  and 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs).  The  Government  will  provide  relevant  information  on 
possible  house  type  plans,  construction  costs  and  techniques,  and  access  to  demonstration 
units5.  Local  CSOs  will  coordinate  the  housing  program,  and  such  coordination  will  include 
interface  between  households,  local  governments,  building  material  suppliers  and  local  micro 
and small-scale building contractors.  
 
7. 
Some  locations  may  need  large-scale  reconstruction,  and  as  a  result,  will  require  the 
engagement  of  centralized  and  large-scale  building  contractors  (footnote  5).  Rehabilitation  of 
such communities may require the relocation of all households. For such relocation, the Urban 
Development  Authority  (UDA)  has  identified  Government  land,  Government  agency-owned 
land, and private land. Most of the land for relocation will be unoccupied Government land. In 
the  event  that  suitable  Government  land  is  not  available,  UDA  will  acquire  land  under  Land 
Acquisition  Act  through  consultation  and  negotiations  and  will  pay  the  land  its  replacement 
value, as prescribed by the national involuntary resettlement policy. In such cases, the guiding 
principles  will  be,  to  the  extent  possible,  to  keep  the  tsunami-affected  communities  at  their 
original locations. The main guiding principle in allocating land plots is that all tsunami-affected 
households will be given to both titled and non-titled households.

9. 
In housing programs, particularly in large-scale community-driven housing programs, the 
construction process will be streamlined. Three processes in this regard are critical: (i) a large 
number of tsunami-affected households lost their land titles, bank documents, and identification 
cards.  This  situation  is  compounded  by  the  fact  that  in  some  districts  land  registries  were 
damaged, and official records were destroyed by the tsunami. In such cases, a mechanism will 
be established to ensure that such factors would not unduly delay recovery and reconstruction. 
(ii) A concise, clear and simplified building codes applicable to the reconstruction process will be 
developed.  Such  building  codes  will  be  adopted  and  will  be  widely  disseminated  among  the 
tsunami-affected  households.  (iii)  An  accelerated  process  to  institutionalize  the  issuance  of 
building permits at local, district, and provincial levels will be established.  
 
10. 
Three issues in respect of construction sector facilitation that need special attention are 
(i) supply of skilled labor at construction sites: initiatives will be provided to support the training 
of skilled construction workers (such as masons, carpenters, plumbers and electricians) through 
vocational training institutional network and through CSOs; (ii) construction materials: Sri Lanka 
will  require  the  support  of  materials  and  equipment  supply  chains;  (iii)  environmental 
management:  an  appropriate  environmental  management  response  for  lime  production  will  be 
installed.  
 
11. 
Assistance to Tsunami-affected Local Authorities. At most tsunami-affected coastal 
areas,  local  authorities  often  do  not  have  the  requisite  institutional  capacity  to  effectively 
manage  large-scale  emergency  assistance  programs.  Therefore,  as  part  of  the  recovery 
process,  these  local  authorities  will  be  assisted  in  developing  and  mainstreaming  consultative 
and inclusive recovery strategies. Project assistance to local authorities includes resources for 
design,  rehabilitation  and/or  reconstruction  of  local  infrastructure  such  as  minor  roads, 
pathways, solid waste management, and street lighting.

Livelihood  Restoration.  Under  both  projects,  livelihood  restoration  support  will  be 
provided to enable tsunami-affected and conflict-affected households to rebuild their livelihood 
sources  or  to  learn  new  employment  skills.  This  will  be  done  by  reviving  local  economies 
through  the  creation  of  jobs  for  locally-based  skilled  and  unskilled  labor.  Livelihood  support 
interventions  include  advisory  services  to  identify  and  develop  suitable  livelihood  options 
including small-scale enterprises, skills development, and transfer of technology. Some of these 
advisory services will be linked with microcredit. Asset replacement support for disadvantaged 
groups on a very competitive basis will also a part of this project component.

Physical Resources 

 
3. 
Sri Lanka sits on a narrow continental shelf 45 kilometers (km) wide in the northeastern 
and northwestern coasts and 8 km along the southeastern and eastern coasts. The country has 
an  area  of  44,250  square  kilometers.  The  northern  shelf  merges  with  India,  forming  an 
extensive  shallow  bank  consisting  of  the  Gulf  of  Mannar,  Palk  Strait,  and  Pedro  Bank.  The 
coastline is 1,770 km.  
 
4. 
The  climate  is  influenced  by  two  monsoon  and  two  inter-monsoon  periods.  The 
southwest  monsoon,  which  occurs  from  May  to  September,  is  associated  with  cyclonic  wind 
circulations  or  depressions  and  is  marked  by  heavy  rainfall,  especially  in  the  southwestern 
seaboard. The northeast monsoon occurs from December to February, and is characterized by 
heavy rainfall more or less confined in the northeastern half of the country, with wind generally

Ecological Resources 

 
5. 
The  natural  ecosystems  within  the  coastal  zone  are  diverse  and  include  lagoons  and 
estuaries,  coral  reefs,  mangrove  swamps,  seagrass  beds,  other  wetlands  and  dune  systems. 
The  country’s  principal  coral  reef  systems  are  composed  of  fringing  reefs  close  to  the  shore. 
Several  offshore  reefs  are  on  the  continental  shelf  off  the  northwestern  coast.  Destructive 
fishing  practices  and  human-induced  activities  such  as  siltation  and  pollution  have  led  to  the 
destruction of the coral reefs. Cumulative damage to mangroves in Sri Lanka has resulted from 
overutilization of the resource and the transformation of large areas for other uses. Mangroves 
have been converted for aquaculture, coconut, and paddy cultivation, and reclaimed for housing 
and  urban  expansion.  The  impact  the  tsunami  has  had  on  these  natural  systems  is  yet  to  be 
studied.  
 
6. 
Sri Lanka is estimated to have over 23,800 hectares of salt marsh lands. Salt marshes in 
the north are found mostly on tidal flats, while in the south, they occur mainly in low areas on the 
sheltered  sides  of  sand  dunes.  The  coastal  marshes  and  wetlands  are  feeding  grounds  for 
migratory waterfowl. Within the tsunami- and conflict-affected areas, around 15 sites have been 
formally designated as protected areas and sanctuaries.

Introduction  

 
 
A. 
 
The  tsunami  seriously  damaged  the  Western  and  Northeastern  coastal  areas  of  Sri 
1. 
Lanka. A needs assessment has been completed to assess the damages to property, livelihood 
and  infrastructure.  In  a  response  a  request  for  emergency  assistance,  ADB  has  prepared  two 
interlinked  projects:  Tsunami-affected  Areas  Rebuilding  Project  (TAARP)  and  North  East 
Community  Restoration  and  Development  Project  II  (NECORD  II)  comprising  components  of 
roads, community infrastructure and shelter, livelihood support, water supply and sanitation, and 
coastal protection. Under these two projects, it is proposed to conduct socioeconomic surveys 
to  identify  and  evaluate  the  socioeconomic  conditions  of  local  communities,  including 
indigenous  communities  who  live  in  marginalized  small  coastal  communities,  and  to  provide 
reconstruction  assistance  to  rebuild  damaged  properties  and  community  infrastructure  as  well 
as livelihood sources through a participatory strategy. The first step is to identify priority areas 
for immediate interventions. About 150 households of indigenous people (Veddas) have thus far 
been  identified  as  affected  by  the  tsunami.  Many  more  Veddas  living  in  Trincomalee  and 
Batticaloa  districts  might  have  also  been  affected  by  the  tsunami;  the  number  of  affected 
indigenous  peoples  could  increase  once  the  socioeconomic  surveys  are  completed.  This 
indigenous  peoples  development  framework  (IPDF)  has  been  formulated  as  the  basis  for  any 
indigenous  peoples  development  plans  (IPDPs)  that  may  be  needed  to  address  indigenous 
peoples’  issues  arising  from  the  subprojects.  The  IPDF  is  intended  to  guide  the  selection  and 
preparation  of  subprojects  under  either  project  to  ensure  better  distribution  of  benefits  to 
indigenous peoples, and rebuild their lost income sources and dwellings.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
”Indigenous peoples” refers to a population with social, cultural, economic, and political 
traditions  and  institutions  distinct  from  the  mainstream  or  dominant  society  or  culture.  ADB’s 
indigenous  peoples  policy  uses  the  following  characteristics  to  define  indigenous  peoples:  (i) 
descent from population groups present in a given area; (ii) maintenance of cultural and social 
identities separate from dominant society and culture; (iii) self-identification and identification by 
others  as  being  part  of  distinct  cultural  group;  (iv)  linguistic  identity  different  from  that  of 
dominant  society;  (v)  social,  cultural,  economic  and  political  traditions  and  institutions  distinct 
from  dominant  culture;  (vi)  economic  systems  more  oriented  towards  traditional  productions 
systems  rather  than  mainstream;  and  (vii)  unique  ties  and  attachments  to  traditional  habitats 
and  ancestral  territories.  Essentially,  indigenous  peoples  have  a  social  and  cultural  identity 
distinct  from  the  main  society,  which  makes  them  vulnerable  to  being  overlooked  in 
development processes.  
 
The  coastal  Vedda’s  communities  retain  a  number  of  social  and  cultural  traditions  and 
3. 
distinct  economic  activities  such  as  group  hunting,  food  gathering  and  fishing.  As  such,  the 
Veddas are, according to ADB’s policy, considered indigenous peoples.

An  IPDP  is  an  integral  part  of  the  project  design  and  includes  provisions  for  project 
implementation, monitoring, and evaluation. An IPDP will consist of (i) preliminary screening, (ii) 
social impact assessment, (iii) mitigation measures, (iv) development assistance, and (v) project 
monitoring. 
 
8. 
Preliminary  Screening.  The  executing  agency  (EA)  and  project  design  and 
implementation  consultants  will  visit  all  tsunami-affected  coastal  communities,  which  come 
under  these  two  projects.  During  these  visits,  the  EA  and  project  design  and  implementation 
consultants  will  arrange  public  meetings  with  village  leaders  of  Vedda  communities  to  collect 
information about their views on project activities and how they address their needs.  

9. 
Social  Impact  Assessment.  The  screening  process  will  identify  indigenous  peoples, 
their  groups,  community-based  organizations,  cultural  traditions,  and  community  structures.  If 
required,  a  social  impact  assessment  (SIA)  will  be  prepared  to  gather  information  on  the 
population and its social, cultural, and economic conditions, and the anticipated social, cultural, 
and economic impacts of the projects, both positive and negative. Focus group meetings will be 
held with community leaders and groups of men and women who have been severely affected 
and  with  those  who  live  in  the  “zones  of  influence”  of  the  proposed  subprojects.  If  the  SIA 
indicates  that  the  subprojects  would  significantly  threaten  cultural  practices  and  sources  of 
livelihood of indigenous peoples, every attempt will be made to avoid or minimize such adverse 
impacts in the formulation and implementation of IPDPs. 
 
10.  Mitigation  Measures.  All  affected  Vedda  households  will  be  helped  to  improve  their 
living standards without exposing their communities to disintegration. As vulnerable groups, they 
are  entitled  to  receive  special  assistance  not  only  to  restore  and  improve  their  income  and 
livelihood,  but  also  to  maintain  their  distinct  cultural  identity.  If  the  subproject  impacts  are  not 
significant and if they could be addressed by resettlement plans that will be prepared according 
to  the  agreed-on  resettlement  framework,  “specific  actions”  could  be  built  into  resettlement

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka:  
The two-decades-long conflict and the recent tsunami have severely affected the communities in these areas. Loss of 
life,  livelihoods,  incomes,  and  property  have  resulted  in  significant  socioeconomic  and  psychological  stress.  In  the 
conflict-affected areas essential investments have not been made for a long time.  
 
The  project  will  provide  shelter  and  reestablish  vital  services  such  as  roads,  fisheries  and  irrigation  infrastructure, 
health  and  educational  facilities,  water  supply,  agricultural  support  services  and  institutions  to  revive  economic 
activities  leading  to  employment,  income  generation,  rehabilitation  of  displaced  persons,  and  restoration  of  social 
stability in these areas.  
 
Improvement  of  services  and  infrastructure  will  also  encourage  people  to  return  to  their  original  villages  and 
settlements. With this end in view, the project will also strengthen health and educational facilities while strengthening 
local level institutions. Community based organizations will be established and supported, saving will be encouraged, 
women will be made more self-reliant, microcredit will be introduced, and recreational facilities will be provided.  
 

B.  Poverty Analysis  
Targeting Classification: Poverty Intervention 
In the North and East, the people affected by the conflict are especially vulnerable due to gender, age, disability, and 
general breakdown in their traditional livelihood systems. Internally displaced people who wish to return to their areas 
of  origin  need  support  in  reestablishing  their  homes  and  their  livelihoods.  Essential  services  such  as  schools, 
hospitals,  clinics,  water  and  power  supply  are  lacking  in  these  areas.  Agricultural  production  has  been  adversely 
affected  by  the  neglect  of  minor  irrigation  schemes.  Surplus  food  production  areas  have  become  food  deficit  areas. 
Livestock numbers have declined. In general the region has suffered extensive dislocation and economic progress has 
been  hampered.  These  problems  have  been  further  aggravated  by  the  tsunami  through  loss  of  lives  and  property. 
Livelihoods  especially  of  fishermen  have  been  destroyed. The  psychological  trauma  from  the  loss  of  lives  has  been 
tremendous.  
 
The  people  in  the  project  areas  face  major  challenges  in  terms  of  basic  human  needs:  shelter,  employment  and 
livelihoods,  access  to  services  (education,  health,  agricultural  support  services,  irrigation,  markets,  power  supply), 
community based institutions.

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: The conflict and the tsunami have resulted in a disproportionate increase 
in the number of women-headed households in the North East. To some extent this is also true in the South after the 
tsunami.  This  presents  significant  challenges  in  these  communities  where  women  traditionally  have  many  other 
disadvantages. Both projects provide opportunities through various components, for both women and men, to restart 
and to initiate livelihood and enterprise activities. The projects will be proactive in identifying the women, households 
headed  by  women,  war  widows,  etc.  in  the  various  communities  who  require  training  in  production-related  skills, 
business  planning,  marketing  skills  and  access  to  credit  and  technical  support  to  enable  them  to  improve  their 
economic strength and contribute to the enhanced well-being of their families. The projects will strengthen the capacity 
of women’s nongovernment organizations so that they can act as resource centers on gender awareness and assist in 
making appropriate investments to improve their livelihoods.
